issues.title: 'tx' HTTP endpoint races with startup
issues.body: core HTTP server starts before we fully load LCL state, which crashes core if `tx` endpoint is called. This also means that all other endpoints may race with core on startup. We should start HTTP server once LCL is done loading.

issues.title: Use `rs-stellar-xdr` instead of cereal for XDR->JSON conversion
Make parallelApply return optional
issues.body:
`TransactionBase::parallelApply` returns a weird sort of sentinel `ParallelTxReturnVal` with empty content on failures. It should just return a `std::optional<ParallelTxReturnVal>`.

(This is a followup for a comment @SirTyson left in review of #5051)

issues.title: Github CI validation doesn't build a version with `--disable-tests`
issues.body: Github CI validation doesn't build a version with `--disable-tests`, which can leads to us merging in a change that only works as a test build, and then fails to compile in Jenkins. We should add a step that just builds core configured with `--disable-tests`.

issues.title: The MinimumSorobanNetworkConfig::MAXIMUM_ENTRY_LIFETIME value is too high for testnet
issues.body: The current value is 1,054,080 (61 days), but we'd like to set it lower on environments like testnet.

issues.title: Enforce copy semantics for BucketList snapshots
issues.body: BucketList snapshots are not thread safe, and each thread must maintain it's own instance. The current interface uses `std::shared_ptr` as the canonical snapshot type, which makes it very easy to accidentally share a snapshot across threads. We should harden this interface, moving away from pointers so it's more difficult to access a single snapshot concurrently.

issues.title: Dead code: remove all in-memory mode flags and docs
issues.body: In-memory mode has been dropped for a long time, yet core still allows in-memory flags (which don't do anything)

issues.title: Integrate apply load benchmarking into CI or release process
issues.body: We should run the apply load benchmarks regularly to have an idea of how changes to the transaction subsystem affect performance. We can add a mission to Supercluster similar to Max TPS.

issues.title: Consider adding thread invariance to Bucket snapshots
issues.body: Since re-using the same snapshot across threads is not safe, it'd be helpful to add invariance similar to what we do in LedgerTxn to ensure we catch any illegal use.

issues.title: mitigate arch-specific behaviour in JIT
issues.body:
Some aspects of the winch JIT -- for example the [stack depth limiting functionality](https://docs.wasmtime.dev/api/wasmtime/struct.Config.html#method.max_wasm_stack) -- may be architecture specific, in the sense that the same check will kick in slightly differently (due to different codegen and register pressure and so forth) on different architectures.

This would produce a new risk of divergence between validators running on different architectures, if we aren't careful. We will probably need to attenuate this somehow, for example through a setting for the conseusus architecture for validators on a given network, or similar.

(There are other approaches such as transforming the wasm to have internal stack limitation code, eg. [this](https://paritytech.github.io/try-runtime-cli/sc_executor_wasmtime/struct.DeterministicStackLimit.html) or [this](https://github.com/near/finite-wasm), rather than relying on the implementation; I expect this would be prohibitively difficult and/or costly, but we can consider it too.)

issues.title: Audit uses of duplicate bucket iteration code
issues.body:
There are a couple parts of core that iterate over the bucket list that should be able to share code. We should audit core to find these uses. Here are a couple -

1. `getLiveBucketListBalanceForAsset` from https://github.com/stellar/stellar-core/pull/4983 can use `loadCompleteBucketListStateHelper`, although this will load all of live state into memory. We could avoid this by changing the helper to loop over buckets from new->old instead of old->new. 
2. `dumpStateArchivalStatistics`

issues.title: Add upper bounds to file types downloaded from untrusted archives as to limit resource utilization
issues.body:
There should be (hardcoded/configurable) maximum sizes for each of the file types that exist in history archives and code should use those upper bounds to limit the amount of work and disk utilization.

Note that this applies to both raw and decompressed payloads

issues.title: Allow all parameters in stellar-core.cfg to be specified as environment variables
issues.body:
## Description
### Explain in detail the additional functionality you would like to see in stellar-core.

Allow all parameters in stellar-core.cfg to be specified as environment variables.

### Explain why this feature is important

Simplify configuration for contexts where it is more convenient to be configured via environment variables. In many modern environments it is simpler to use environment variables. On developer machines and in scripts it is often easier to use environment variables.

It is one of the more inconvenient things I experience about configuring stellar-core when I use it in docker containers, or in scripts.

### Describe the solution you'd like

If no stellar-core.cfg is provided it looks for environment variables for the fields in the TOML file. If an environment variable exists with the same name as a field, it is used instead. For tables in the TOML, those are mapped to environment variables per field.

To not reinvent the wheel on how to do this, it would be ideal if this worked how tools in the Rust ecosystem have implemented environment variable to toml file mapping:
> Keys are converted to uppercase, dots and dashes are converted to underscores. For example the `target.x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu.runner` key can also be defined by the `CARGO_TARGET_X86_64_UNKNOWN_LINUX_GNU_RUNNER` environment variable.

Ref: https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/config.html#environment-variables.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

It is possible to use templating tools to push environment variables into the file format, but this is more complexity rather than less.

### Additional context

It is very common for hosted services and tools to support configurations via files and environment variables.

Horizon and many services do this.

Cargo is a good example of a CLI interface that supports .toml files and environment variables, and even though it has complex tables, every field in its tomls is overridable via an environment variable. For example: https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/config.html#environment-variables.

Some files are getting quite large.

We probably need to split/refactor them.

issues.title: Audit usage of shared pointers to non-const values
Consider changing how we calculate metrics
issues.body:
Right now, the way we update metrics that track absolute numbers is by carefully updating those metrics at the same time (when updating containers for example).

This is quite error prone (we keep metrics up to date at a much too granular level) and causes the code to be littered with `set_count`.

We should instead consider adding an `updateMetrics` to all classes, and have the `metrics` endpoint call those. This would follow a similar pattern than the methods that produce json.

issues.title: Test-Related Headers are Indirectly Included in Non-Test Files
issues.body: There are many test-related headers that are included in files where they aren't needed, and some of these includes propagate all the way up to files like main/ApplicationImpl.cpp. We should clean this up. Tangentially related to #2408.

issues.title: Check for use of abort and assert in invariants
issues.body: Noticed while reviewing #2708, although the issue already existed. Slightly related to #2094.

issues.title: Fix Naming Convention in util/Math.h
issues.body: Functions in this file do not match our naming convention. Discovered when reviewing https://github.com/stellar/stellar-core/pull/2880.

issues.title: Add Additional Tests for Fee-Bump Replace-by-Fee
issues.body: Right now, we don't have any test where a transaction with few operations replaces a transaction with many operations. Discovered while reviewing #2880.

issues.title: Rework removeEntryWithPossibleSponsorship to Create a Child LedgerTxn
issues.body: The same will have to be done for related functions like `removeSignerWithPossibleSponsorship`. Overall, this should make the interface safer and easier to use.

issues.title: suggestion: consolidate meta generation
issues.body:
While reviewing https://github.com/stellar/stellar-core/pull/3093 I realized that we have an opportunity to harden a bit how we store meta in the database:
right now meta is stored in a variable `mNextMetaToEmit` that gets streamed in captive core mode and also stored in historical tables "inline" when closing a ledger.

We could instead use exclusively a member similar to `mNextMetaToEmit` inside the various steps to close a ledger, managed by `LedgerTxn` that way the translation into sql (or whatever else) is done by the root txn object.

This would allow to:
* have captive core and non-captive core paths use the same source of truth for meta
* remove "one off" sql statements done outside of "ledgertxn" - over time we want LedgerTxn to be the only way to write into tables

issues.title: Use trustlineKey instead of constructing LedgerKey directly
issues.body: In some places (such as ChangeTrustOpFrame.cpp and Upgrades.cpp), we construct `LedgerKey` directly instead of using `trustlineAsset`. We should clean this up.

issues.title: Move some LedgerTxn interfaces into separate files
issues.body: https://github.com/stellar/stellar-core/pull/3093#discussion_r661949351 revealed that some interfaces are only defined in LedgerTxnImpl.h despite being needed elsewhere. A big reason of having an "Impl" is containing the implementation details where they are actually needed. Clearly this goal isn't being fully achieved. This is low priority.

issues.title: Add a helper function to read data from JSON that may not be present
issues.body: This [comment thread](https://github.com/stellar/stellar-core/pull/3178#discussion_r695896416) shows that we are repeatedly using a specific pattern to read data from JSON that may not be present. We should add a helper for this so that (a) we don't have to remember the specific pattern each time (b) the name makes it clear what we are doing.

issues.title: Improve liquidity pool trade tests

We are going to merge #3207, but there are a few residual test improvements that can be made, as noted in

issues.title: Update LedgerHeader before applying buckets
issues.body: #3233 revealed the version-dependent database input checks can fail during bucket apply. This is fixed in #3235, but not in an elegant way. A better solution would allow us to update the header first. We might already be able to do this, or we might need to use the rebuild-buckets functionality to make this work.

issues.title: Fuzzer should adjust balances correctly
issues.body: The fuzzer doesn't handle all possible balance adjustments after setup, for example see https://github.com/stellar/stellar-core/pull/3245#discussion_r783273534. We should fix this to make it easier to maintain in the future.

issues.title: Simplify captive core startup
issues.body: Currently, there are two paths in captive core: one rebuilds the state by applying buckets, and the other one synchronously performs catchup. With changes introduced in https://github.com/stellar/stellar-core/pull/3282, we should be able to use a single path that triggers catchup on startup (but with different configs). This will yield simpler and easier to follow code.

issues.title: Clean Up Python Scripts

The current Python scripts in `scripts/` have undocumented dependencies (`HistogramGenerator.py` requires `numpy` and `OverlaySurvey.py` requires `networkx` and `requests`). issues.title: LedgerEntry context ID / provenance tracking
issues.body:
This is a suggestion about something new we could do in core to minimize risks of data consistency issues.

### Background: LedgerTxn

Stellar core has a somewhat-centralized system for accessing the ledger called `LedgerTxn` (a.k.a. LTX) which is a sort of nested key/value map (mapping `LedgerKey` to `LedgerEntry`) that is used for several overlapping purposes:

1. Atomic commit/rollback (with exception safety) of multiple simultaneous changes.
2. Batching and caching accesses to the underlying database and/or buckets.
3. Minimizing the risk of data consistency errors.

This third task is subtle and the source of a lot of the complexity of the LTX: doing a lookup on an LTX produces a `LedgerTxnEntry` object, which is _not_ a raw `LedgerEntry`. The `LedgerTxnEntry` is instead a special smart pointer type that can be _invalidated at a distance_ by the ltx it came from. In particular when a parent LTX opens a child LTX, all existing `LedgerTxnEntry`s issued by _past lookups on the parent_ are dynamically invalidated, wherever they may be. Any attempt to read or write through them will fail (dynamically, at runtime).

The _purpose_ of it is to avoid two types of data inconsistency that can arise if a child LTX has newer entries than its parent:

1. Stale reads from the parent LTX that should be hidden by the child LTX's newer entry.
2. Lost writes to a parent LTX entry that will be overwritten by the child LTX's newer entry.

The purpose is good! But the _implementation_ of this leaves some things to be desired:

1. It makes use of destructors in a way that's not very obvious to the user. A lot of users don't know when they can or should call `.current()` on a `LedgerTxnEntry`.
2. It is relatively easy to accidentally subvert by capturing a reference to the underlying `LedgerEntry` in a local.
3. The implementation is quite confusing and involves a _lot_ of code and complexity for just this one task.
4. The implementation is tightly coupled to the `LedgerTxn` class itself, and does nothing to prevent similar inconsistencies in contexts where we don't or can't use the `LedgerTxn` class (eg. when operating directly on bucket lists and snapshots, or in the new parallel apply subsystem).

### Alternative: LedgerEntry context IDs / provenances

I propose we explore alternative designs to the LTX, not necessarily replacing it wholesale (or not yet) but as a first step factoring out the _purpose_ of its inconsistency-prevention system into a separate _mechanism_ that:

1. Is much simpler and has much less machinery
2. Is easier to understand, more explicit, and harder to accidentally misuse
3. most importantly: we actually _can_ use everywhere we use `LedgerEntry`s, not just in LTXs

The mechanism I have in mind has two pieces:

1. A `LedgerEntryContext` class that is lightweight and can either be separately inherited-from or manually instantiated anywhere there's a conceptual collection of `LedgerEntry`s that need to be guarded against stale reads or lost updates. This class contains a _number_ (no complex pointer types) that we arrange to uniquely identify the context in the code (exact mechanism of assigning numbers TBD; some mix of static and dynamic numbering, but assume there's some way of uniquely numbering them). We can call these "context IDs" or "provenances" depending on your taste.
2. A `LedgerEntryWrapper` class that _directly contains_ a  `LegerEntry` and so can be passed to and from functions, put in standard container types, buffered, cached, etc. etc. Additionally, this class carries the number of a context that the wrapper is associated with (it is set on construction).

These two pieces would collaborate to dynamically check a similar condition: that nobody reads or writes entries "in a context they shouldn't". Contexts need not be containers! Or if they are containers, they need not be containers shaped exactly like a map from keys to values (for example bucket lists and eviction iterators are more like just sequences or lists of entries).

I can think of at least 3 mechanisms of enforcement of such "context-sensitive access":

1. In order to _read from_ or _write to_ the `LedgerEntry` inside a `LedgerEntryWrapper`, a method like `context.unwrap_read(wrapper, [](LedgerEntry const&) { ... })` or `context.unwrap_write(wrapper, [](LedgerEntry&) {...})` needs to be called on a context. This method checks the context numbers match before allowing access and throws if they do not. Since it takes a closure it's less immediately easy to capture the reference in a local variable (it's not impossible -- at some level there's no way to prevent it -- but it's a little harder!)
2. Contexts may want to activate or de-activate themselves entirely -- masking off the possibility of _any_ access to a parent context while a child is open -- the same way LTXs do, with parent/child relationships tracked by a helper flag/method/destructor if needed. But not all contexts we're concerned about have a direct parent/child coupling in the call tree the same way LTXs do, so this might not be the only way of using them.
3. The assignment `operator=` of `LedgerEntryWrapper` may also want to contain a dynamic check that the assigned number matches the existing number, such that writing back a `LedgerEntryWrapper` to a container will fail unless the numbers match. For this to work there needs to either be a (partial?) order on numbers such that child-context entries _can_ overwrite parent-context entries when being committed-back to them, or else if numbers are opaque there needs to be a way to _intentionally_ re-home a bunch of wrappers (eg. by calling a method `wrapper.set_context(new_context)` on all of them before writing back.

### Longer term: the LTX itself

The LTX is a bit of a maintenance concern. The code is very complex, it is strictly sequential (not parallel friendly), I am very unsure of its exception-safety logic, much of it is now semi-redundant with the parallel apply path and the underlying bucketlist (which already does its own caching and batching), and its SQL caching and batching function (or SQL-access mediation at all) is no longer used for anything other than the orderbook.

While I do not want to dismiss the extent to which the orderbook is still a central use-case, I think it could be a healthy de-risking of the future of LTX client code to start finding ways to accomplish the remainder of what the LTX does without actually needing it. Or alternatively to refactoring its implementation to "meet the same goals" with a simpler internal implementation. I believe that if the LTX implemented this `LedgerEntryContext` interface, LTX client code could fairly easily be ported over to it piece by piece, after which a lot of the internal complexity of the LTX could be eliminated (retaining the pieces it needs to function as a transactional nested map and cache of orderbook state, again at least for now). I think this could even eventually make room for a standard tx-apply path that doesn't use the LTX at all -- only the new parallel apply machinery -- if we could find a parallel-friendly answer for the orderbook.

issues.title: Add State Archival Invariant
issues.body: Add state archival consistency invariants (entry can exist in one bucketlist only, along with its ttl, no orphaned ttls should exist, entries to evict must be present in live state and match the newest version, entries to restore must be present in archived state and match the newest version, etc)

issues.title: Add INFO level log message tracking validator nomination timeouts
issues.body: We should log the current round leader(s) at the INFO level when a nomination timeout occurs. See [this slack thread](https://stellarfoundation.slack.com/archives/C0367MGFL/p1761584825554909) for more context.

issues.title: Write CAP to simplify Eviction Scan
issues.body: Write a cap to simplify the eviction scan, using in-memory state instead of BucketList scanning.

issues.title: Replace background eviction scan with simplified blocking scan
issues.body: Once we have updated eviction scan to use in-memory state via #4999, we will still need to support BucketList based scanning for protocol 20-24. However, since it will only be required for catchup and we're disk bound anyway, there's no reason to maintain background scanning. We can simplify the code by replacing it with a blocking scan.

issues.title: Add inexpensive in-memory update invariant
issues.body: When updating the in-memory soroban cache, we should add an invariant that checks that the result of the update matches what is written to the BucketList. We can do this cheaply by just checking the in-memory cache against the INIT, LIVE, and DEAD entry vectors that the BucketList gives to `addBatch` instead of actually doing disk loads.

issues.title: Thorough in-memory soroban state cache invariant
issues.body: We should add an invariant that periodically scans the entire BucketList and in-memory soroban cache, ensuring the two are consistent. This would be expensive, so it probably requires something like #5002

issues.title: Investigate randomized testing for eviction and restoration related events
Unify code between `LedgerManagerForBucketTests` and `LedgerManager`
Harden TTL load paths
issues.body:
Currently, TTL and it's affiliated ContractData/ContractCode must be loaded separately. However, there should be no reason to load a data/code entry without it's associated TTL, so this interface can lead to footguns. We should refactor such that both the TTL and associated data/code entry are loaded at the same time and returned as some unified struct.

I believe @graydon is already working on hardening the data access layer with some compile time checks and type aliasing in #4971, so we should probably hold of on this until that is finished.

issues.title: Add new SAC transfer apply load mission
issues.body:
We should add a new mission (or missions) that use stellar-core's `apply-load` mode for SAC transfers. The mission(s) should support the following:

1. max SAC TPS
2. limit-based apply load with the current network limits (to catch regressions in the apply time more holistically)
3. customizable limit-based apply load for SLPs.

We should build this with stellar/stellar-core#5021 in mind. Additionally, this mission should ensure that it uses the same machine for all benchmarking (perhaps by making use of node labels?), and additionally should support iops limiting, [like the benchmarking setup for SLP-001](https://github.com/stellar/stellar-protocol/blob/master/limits/slp-0001.md#benchmarking).

issues.title: Unified fuzz-harness interface
issues.body:
Over the years we've created or contracted the creation of several different fuzz harnesses (the tx fuzzer, an overlay fuzzer, a half dozen soroban fuzzers). 

These have all to varying extent suffered from neglect:
  - Some don't even get committed/merged into any main repos (eg. they're just part of audit contracts)  
  - Some don't all get built or checked for correct function regularly
  - Some (most? all?) don't get run continuously
  - We're not in oss-fuzz in particular
  - They're not integrated into (pseudo-)randomized unit testing very well (we use an ancient version of autocheck; it might be nice to try to expose such tests as miniature fuzz harnesses (eg. in github.com/google/fuzztest)

It would be nice to have a bit more unified infrastructure for fuzzing to address these shortcomings. Ideally we'd have:

  - [ ] a single top-level entrypoint dispatching to all existing fuzz harnesses in core and soroban
  - [ ] that is merged into master and built-and-run-a-bit as part of CI so it never breaks
  - [ ] that is driven by the best option for fuzzer engines (probably honggfuzz)
  - [ ] that is registered with oss-fuzz for continuous fuzzing on google infra
  - [ ] that is easy and obvious to extend with new harnesses when we contract for them
  - [ ] bonus: that is connected in some way to unit tests so they can naturally get registered as more harnesses

issues.title: Core restarts are slow and result in catchup due to core in-memory state populating on startup
issues.body: version v23.0.1, observed on a dev watcher - looks like stellar-core blocks for ~30 seconds on startup to populate soroban in-memory state. We should probably buffer ledgers while rebuilding state to minimize chances of core falling back to catchup (especially if we anticipate rebuild time to increase).

issues.title: Audit core limits that depend on network op limits
issues.body:
Looks like a few places in core don't take into account Soroban limits. Examples are:

- [ ] Pull mode https://github.com/stellar/stellar-core/blob/86a346adf8dd48d32e4ea02c27dc978f07e81011/src/overlay/TxAdverts.cpp#L111
- [ ] outbound queues https://github.com/stellar/stellar-core/blob/86a346adf8dd48d32e4ea02c27dc978f07e81011/src/overlay/FlowControl.cpp#L406

Currently, this isn't much of a problem since Soroban limits are still very low. But we should fix this to support higher limits.

issues.title: Grafana: BucketListDB Duration metric is showing some empty graphs
issues.body: "All" isn't a valid type, so those two graphs should be removed.

issues.title: Incorrect warning to std err
issues.body:
@Shaptic mentioned that captive-core is outputting the following log
```
level=info msg="Warning: running non-release version stellar-core 23.0.0 (d5cbc0793d6eab25eac886969c5bc0f7da69d6ea) of stellar-core" pid=1 subservice=stellar-core
```

The parsing of the version  is probably incorrect, and we should also updated this to log instead of `cerr`.

issues.title: Tracking issue for C++ 20 upgrade
issues.body:
### What
Creating a list of things to revisit after C++ 20 upgrade of stellar-core.

- [ ] Simplify [InternalInMemoryBucketEntry](https://github.com/SirTyson/stellar-core/blob/3cd1714b4cb4c7b0416e223cffcbe126ea79ac84/src/bucket/InMemoryIndex.h#L26) using heterogeneous lookup in unordered_set
- [ ] xdrpp 
- [ ] Replace the `gcc` `##__VA_ARGS__`-extension with the C++ 20 standard `__VA_OPT__`.
- [ ] Constrain templates using concepts where appropriate

issues.title: Remove v20-dependent dead code in overlay/herder
issues.body: There are several v20 checks in overlay/herder/tx queue. Now that the network is way past v20, all that code can be cleaned up. For example, we don't need to wait to externalize to initialize soroban tx queue (it doesn't need to be a pointer anymore). We should search for `protocolVersionStartsFrom(protocolVersion, SOROBAN_PROTOCOL_VERSION)` and remove dead code where appropriate.

issues.title: Wire up XDR version checking for rust quorum checker on startup
issues.body:
The new quorum checker uses [stellar-quorum-analyze](https://github.com/stellar/stellar-quorum-analyzer)  that depends on XDR's quorum definitions.
We should wire up versioning checking to ensure the same version is being used.

issues.title: `generalized tx set XDR conversion` test is flaky
issues.body: The `apply order is shuffled` subsection of the `generalized tx set XDR conversion` test occasionally fails in github CI. Rerunning the job tends to fix it, so there's some nondeterminism in the test somewhere that's causing it to occasionally fail. The test was introduced in #4848.

issues.title: Investigate and implement consensus and execution pipelining
Provide useful debug information when an invalid soroban settings upgrade is used
issues.body: At the moment, `dumpProposedSettings` returns the message `configUpgradeSet is missing or invalid` if there's an issue with the proposed settings. The `upgrade` command also just returns `Error setting configUpgradeSet` on error. We should instead mention which setting is invalid.

issues.title: survey: use Radar instead of Stellarbeat
issues.body: Stellarbeat is reaching EOL soon, we should switch to [Radar](https://radar.withobsrvr.com/api/docs/)

issues.title: loadgen: add `status` mode to the http command
issues.body:
Loadgen has gotten pretty complex with all the different modes and configurations. The problem is that when misconfigured, it just reports a generic failure in metrics. This makes debugging downstream harder, as consumers don't know what the error is without accessing core logs directly.

We should add a new mode `status` that reports the most recent loadgen error status, if any.

issues.title: Add Support for Hot Archive HAS to Stellar Archivist
issues.body: With the introduction of State Archival in p23, we are changing the History Archive format. This will require the corresponding changes in stellar-archivist. Given there's been lots of issues with the tool and it's an outdated go library, this may be a good opportunity to just rewrite it in something like rust and have the core team maintain it more actively going forward.

issues.title: Update `network config snapshots Soroban state size` test
issues.body: The `network config snapshots Soroban state size` test is semi-broken right now: it only works with in-memory DB and is not compatible with the window size upgrades. It should be updated to close the ledgers with the actual transactions instead of writing the mock ledger entries. Or alternative the test LE generation code should be fixed to work properly with the upgrades and the default DB mode.

issues.title: Make `modifySorobanNetworkConfig` update only the necessary settings
issues.body: Currently `modifySorobanNetworkConfig` and the underlying loadgen settings upgrade machinery just unconditionally write all the config ledger entries. Instead, it should only update the settings that have changed. Also, we use the optional fields to determine if the respective setting field needs to be written in the upgrade. This only works because the optional values are never nullopt. We should instead look at the whole entry XDR and upgrade the whole entry if anything has changed.

issues.title: Some test cases are only running for the latest protocol, missing bugs made to the previous protocol
issues.body: The `"History catchup"` test and the `"settings upgrade command line utils"` tests both use `TEST_CASE`, instead of `TEST_CASE_VERSIONS`, and both of those tests would've caught bugs if they ran for the previous protocol. We should update these two tests, and also go through the tests in `InvokeHostFunctionOp` to make sure any test that can use `TEST_CASE_VERSIONS` is updated.

issues.body:
Looking at [Stellar Beat](https://www.stellarbeat.io/organizations) it looks like there history archives are getting corrupted somehow.

At this time, I am seeing the following corruptions (on tier 1 validators):

Start repair at ledger 23999998 with [Stellar Archivist](https://github.com/stellar/go/tree/master/tools/stellar-archivist) and purge your cache afterwards.`

issues.title: Reminder: Check latest protocol cost types against budget.rs
issues.body: When the cost types are recalibrated in env, we updated this loop in [budget.rs](https://github.com/stellar/rs-soroban-env/blob/cf469d2d4be82f83c24b75aeb8a133cfb82a23cd/soroban-env-host/src/budget.rs#L294). Those values also need to be reflected in stellar-core on protocol upgrades, but it's easy to forget to make that change. We should expose those values from env, and write a test case in stellar-core that validates it's own cost types against env.

issues.title: Investigate and implement fetching blocks in parallel with nomination
Consolidated events vs meta in core [Discussion]
issues.body:
Related to https://github.com/stellar/stellar-protocol/discussions/1553 (standardize on how classic token transfer/clawback/min/burn events can be represented).

One way to think about how those events are generated is that they are the result of some transformation of the â€œrawâ€  meta `TransactionMetaV3` at the transaction and operation level (`LedgerEntryChanges` and potentially with some information from `Transaction` and `TransactionResult`).

For most modern use cases that need to support Soroban, the â€œrawâ€ format is not useful, and systems instead need to rely on consolidated events.

This opens the possibility that the transformation above could be performed at the core layer.

There are a few advantages with this approach:
  * The size of the meta gets reduced (by over 60% for path payments)
  * There is standardization of the unified events at the lowest level of the stack, and protocol details are not leaked downstream (not the case if events are only relying on operation type and `LedgerEntryChanges`).
  * Opens the door to trusted unified events in the future

Disadvantages:
  * The size savings may not be big enough to counter the additional complexity in core and downstream to support all combinations of data
  * Additional complexity for operators that need to adjust their configuration in order to generate â€œfull metaâ€ (or all sorts of variations, some systems may need to track actual values for some ledger entries like WASM or NFT metadata)
  * Iterations over this will require regeneration of the entire meta data lake for each iteration (and associated reingestion by all downstream systems)
  * Downstream needs to transform the data anyways, in particular when enabling filtering (where the larger gains in terms of data size are) in the early stage of the CDP.

### Appendix

Ledger Entry average sizes (2025-01-15):
  * Account = 127
  * Offer = 139
  * TrustLine = 129
 
#### Path Payment

##### Meta size estimation

Asset/Asset path payment will touch: Src trustline, offer + counterparty trustlines, dest trustline
`129+(139+2*129)+129=655` bytes

Meta for before/after -> `655*2=1,310` bytes.
 
##### Event size estimation
 
Each transfer 
`16+3*32+4*8+16=160` (if in the form "transfer", source, destination, asset issuer/contract, amount)
Or `160+57+4=221` if including asset string (with the asset code anywhere from 1 to 12 characters)
 
2 transfers are `160*2=320` or `221*2=442` bytes.
 
A saving of `1310-442=868` bytes (66%).

For a longer path payments, savings are even higher.

issues.title: Audit and harden concurrent access to SCP history tables used during consensus and publishing
issues.body:
Currently in master `scphistory` and `scpquorums` are accessed concurrently:
* SCP history is written during consensus on the main thread (append-only)
* During publish, SCP history is queried from the background thread (select rows)
* During maintenance, SCP history is deleted (delete rows)

This seems to work as we haven't run into a single serialization issue for years (probably because we don't touch the same rows), but it's definitely a footgun. If we change any of these queries, we may run into concurrent DB access errors (and triggering those might be quite difficult, so hard to say when it'd get discovered)

We should:
* Confirm this actually works
* Write documentation on these queries
* Consider just doing checkpoint building on the main thread. Tx history maintenance burden has been significantly reduced as of v22.1.0, so it seems plausible we could construct the checkpoint on the main thread without much overhead.

issues.title: Harden leader election to unresponsive nodes and asymmetric quorums
issues.body:
There are a couple scenarios that can lead to elevated nomination timeouts:
1. Slow or missing validators that do not respond when they are elected as the round leader, and
2. Asymmetric quorums leading to disagreements about the leader.

One way to solve (1) is to track the responsiveness of other validators to nomination over some window of time and fast-timeout when picking an unresponsive node. By using a fast timeout, the network will elect 2+ leaders: the unresponsive node(s) and a responsive node. The tradeoff is that there may be multiple values on the network when the unresponsive node(s) become responsive again. However, this will resolve itself once those nodes are marked responsive again.

This solution may also indirectly help with situation (2) as asymmetric quorums will lead to some nodes with differing quorum sets being marked unresponsive, and therefore multiple nodes will win leader election and the probability of the network agreeing on a leader will increase. However, it's worth discussing whether a more direct solution exists here.

issues.title: BucketListIsConsistentWithDatabase is too agressive
issues.body: Currently, `BucketListIsConsistentWithDatabase` checks the SQL offer table against the BucketList for consistency after every call to `assumeState`. This is too aggressive, as this check is expensive. We should instead only call this invariant after actually updating the offers table after `BucketApply`, not on every `assumeState` call.

issues.title: Missing operation.go file on processors package
issues.body:
<!-- Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks! -->
### What problem does your feature solve?
The current go-stellar-sdk is missing the operation.go file that was present in the previous package github.com/stellar/go. This file provided access to TransactionOperationWrapper and its associated methods, which are essential for processing transaction operations in my indexer implementation.
Without this functionality, there's no clear migration path for developers who relied on these utilities in the previous SDK version.

### What would you like to see?
I would like to see operation.go added back to the SDK, or alternatively, clear documentation on:

1. The replacement/equivalent functionality for TransactionOperationWrapper
2. Migration guide from github.com/stellar/go to the current SDK structure
3. Recommended patterns for handling transaction operation wrapping

Adding operation.go (or its equivalent) would significantly facilitate development and provide continuity for developers migrating from the previous SDK version.

issues.title: Design stellar integration testing library
issues.body:
Spike to come up with a proposal for an integration testing library that can spin up ephemeral standalone networks for the purposes of testing downstream systems. This testing library can be modeled after what we currently use for horizon integration tests. Potential use cases for this library are:

- horizon integration tests
- rpc integration tests
- galexie integration tests
- integration tests downstream of horizon / rpc

The library should provide the option of spinning up a core validator and (optionally) horizon / rpc

issues.title: contracts: generate ScVals from contract fn specs
issues.body:
<!-- Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks! -->

### What problem does your feature solve?
Go SDK doesn't have capability to generate request parameter ScVals for a contract function defined on a contract spec. 

### What would you like to see?
Determine the best interface approach in SDK for DX concerns and provide the implementation of chosen approach.

* Option 1 - generate go code(bindings) for a given conract fn's. Applications follow a two step process.
  * step 1 - use a cli tool to generate code as bindings for a given contract and fn
  * step 2- integrate generated bindings code to application code.
  * prior poc for reference - https://github.com/stellar/go-stellar-sdk/pull/5806  
* Option 2 - dynamic helper functions
  * New functional component added to `contract` package which provides ability for client to generate request parameter ScVals given a contract and a function name.
    * input - contract Wasm bytes or contract id/wasm hash for on-chain contract wasm code retrieval. 
    * input - the contract fn name
    * input - list of parameter argument values expressed as go types to be applied as the args to the contract fn.
    * return - slice of ScVals in same order as the input parameters argument values
    * checkout the stellar-js-sdk [Spec.funcArgsToScVals](https://github.com/stellar/js-stellar-sdk/blob/master/src/contract/spec.ts#L587) for a complete implementation reference.  




### What alternatives are there?

issues.title: Add wrappers to rpcclient to simplify for common ledger entry fetches
issues.body:
At minimum, introduce

- [ ] `getAccountEntry` 
- [ ] `getTrustline`
- [ ] `getClaimableBalance`

You can use https://github.com/stellar/js-stellar-sdk/pull/1221 and https://github.com/stellar/js-stellar-sdk/pull/1218 as references.

issues.title: Add URL() method to rpcclient.Client to expose configured URL
issues.body:
### What problem does your feature solve?

The `rpcclient.Client` struct stores the RPC URL internally but doesn't expose it:

```go
type Client struct {
	url        string  // unexported
	cli        *jrpc2.Client
	mx         sync.RWMutex
	httpClient *http.Client
}
```

When wrapping the client in another type, there's no way to retrieve the URL it was configured with. This is useful for debugging, logging, and testing purposes.

For comparison, `horizonclient.Client` has an exported `HorizonURL` field that can be accessed directly.

### What would you like to see?

Add a `URL()` method to `rpcclient.Client` that returns the configured URL:

```go
// URL returns the RPC server URL this client is configured to use.
func (c *Client) URL() string {
	return c.url
}
```

### What alternatives are there?

1. **Store a duplicate copy of the URL** - This is what we're currently doing in [stellar/friendbot](https://github.com/stellar/friendbot) when wrapping the client, but it's redundant since the client already has this information.

2. **Export the `url` field** - Change `url` to `URL` to make it exported. However, a getter method is preferred as it maintains encapsulation and allows for future flexibility.

issues.title: Not have httpjson always render pretty-formatted JSON
issues.body:
### What problem does your feature solve?

Can possibly save a lot in data size when rendering JSON, more specifically, when rendering responses for the Horizon API.

### What would you like to see?

Currently, the `httpjson` package renders JSON API output data by ultimately calling its `RenderStatus` function, which always calls the `renderToString` function setting `true` as the value of the `pretty` parameter.

My suggestion is to have the `renderToString` be called with `false` as the default value, which will probably be more efficient when consuming JSON data from the API if we don't need pretty JSON data.
A nice-to-have would be to have a query parameter or something like that in Horizon which we could use to control the value that's passed to the `pretty` param of the `renderToString` function.

If that's of any interest, I've implemented a POC (don't know if this breaks anything) of this in my local fork, see this commit: https://github.com/GCrispino/go-stellar-sdk/commit/2f3093962f6542fa48a8f7f664f4893b130e13c7

### What alternatives are there?
None, to the best of my knowledge.

issues.title: Investigate supply chain security score (75/100) on Socket.dev
issues.body:
The `go-stellar-sdk` package currently has a supply chain security score of **75/100** on socket.dev: https://socket.dev/go/package/github.com/stellar/go-stellar-sdk.

As an SDK used by developers building on Stellar, and developers should be able to have confidence in the SDK's stability and suitability, we should understand what factors are contributing to this score and see if we can address them.

issues.title: ingest: use of strict captive-core config makes horizon/soroban-rpc unnecessarily incompatible with new stellar-core features
issues.body:
The `ingest` package allows its users to specify whether the stellar-core config files should be loaded in strict mode. Strict mode causes the ingest package to check that all fields in the config are known to the ingest package.

The problem with this is that the ingest package largely passes through this config to stellar-core, and stellar-core has config options that the ingest package doesn't know about.

This strict behavior prevents developers from using new features of stellar-core, or old features unknown to ingest, without making code changes to ingest and waiting for horizon to be re-released.

The comment in the code is also misleading. It states that setting strict to true will reject fields not supported by stellar-core. However, it rejects fields not known to ingest, even if they are supported by stellar-core.

https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/8371bee88deb9a99922d7e1107e9eb8754fc4dc7/ingest/ledgerbackend/toml.go#L324-L325

issues.title: support/datastore: add http datastore.
issues.body:
This requirement has been discussed with @johncanneto.

### What problem does your feature solve?

As a data provider, we might offer data generated by Galaxie to our users. However, using Cloudflare R2 as an example, the only way to provide public access currently is by directly exposing an HTTP endpoint. Of course, as a provider, we could add an S3 proxy layer in front of it, but I feel this complicates things unnecessarily.

Therefore, I hope that the datastore layer can directly support HTTP as a data source. This would simplify the data access workflow.

### What would you like to see?
The ability to directly support HTTP as a data source in the datastore layer.



### What alternatives are there?
N/A

issues.title: ingest/loadtest: Spike - consider external tool approach
issues.body: ### What problem does your feature solve? The design approach for integrating the loadtest package internally into a target application's ingestion code path such as demonstrated on #5794 for Horizon and equally applicable in other apps targeted for using loadtest like rpc or galexie introduces some tight coupling between the app and loadtest going forward. ### What would you like to see? * load testing is transparent to the application * no coupling from application code to loadtest, applications have a net zero-code adjustment to use loadtest. * analyze an alternative for leveraging the existing [go/ingest/loadtest](https://github.com/stellar/go/tree/master/ingest/loadtest) to be packaged as a 'blackbox' cli tool and can be invoked as a substitute in place of the usual captive core bin. Applications set their `CAPTIVE_CORE_BIN=loadtest_tool`, the cli tool bin mocks the 'catchup' and 'run' parameter invocations. ### What alternatives are there? Change the application ingestion code path to Integrate with [go/ingest/loadtest](https://github.com/stellar/go/tree/master/ingest/loadtest) and establish new app config parameters related to loadtest such as demonstrated [here](https://github.com/stellar/go/pull/5794) for Horizon.

issues.title: support/errors: mark and document that support/errors is deprecated
issues.body:
Given @shaptic's comments below we should mark and document that support/errors is deprecated so that folks avoid writing new code using it.

> We've been trying to move away from this package which is basically an ancient ancestor that was written prior to Go's native [`errors`](https://pkg.go.dev/errors) package being actually decent. Instead of `Wrapf` we've been using `errors.Join`, `fmt.Errorf`, etc.

_Originally posted by @Shaptic in https://github.com/stellar/go/pull/5708#discussion_r2104998019_

issues.title: ingest: Prevent multi-ledger compaction in ChangeCompactor
issues.body:
### What 
Add a check to prevent a single [ChangeCompactor](https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/master/ingest/change_compactor.go) instance from processing changes from multiple ledger sequences.

See https://github.com/stellar/go/pull/5587#issuecomment-2664554932 for more details.

### Why
The [ChangeCompactor](https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/master/ingest/change_compactor.go) is designed to combine changes for the same ledger entry within a single ledger. Currently, it's possible to use a single ChangeCompactor instance to process changes from multiple ledgers.



### What Alternatives are there?
Leave it to the users of the ingest library to ensure it is used correctly for a single ledger.

issues.title: ingest: captive-core: output offline-info logs
issues.body:
The captive core backend invokes `stellar-core offline-info`:

https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/b589529f102f0b92c106e1015a80531f52623036/ingest/ledgerbackend/run_from.go#L42-L58


However:

1. It doesn't print it's logs (stderr) as it executes. This is confusing when `offline-info` requires indexing (which can take more than 4 minutes). The user doesn't know what's going on during that time.
2. It doesn't print its output in case of error.

issues.title: txnbuild/transaction: add a way of doing external signing of transactions without transaction.Sign(..)
issues.body:
### What problem does your feature solve?
This allows users of the stellar-go library to implement their own signing algorithm. This is beneficial for anyone wanting to sign without having direct access to the private key (and thus cannot produce the required KeyPair), such as when using a cold wallet or using a secret shared private key. 

### What would you like to see?
The signing algorithm requires hashing the TransactionEnvelope, which is currently a private property (envelope) of the Transaction type. Once this envelope has been hashed and signed, this has to be set in the transaction, something that also cannot be done (without using clone(...) of txnbuild/transaction). Therefore, adding either a way of getting the envelope directly (like done [here](https://github.com/Pownieh/stellar_go/blob/8682b386febf735239031167cdf24971dce0d47f/txnbuild/transaction.go#L295-L297)), or adding a specific way of getting the hash of the envelope and then afterwards setting the signatures, would allow someone to implement their own signing protocol. 

### What alternatives are there?
Alternatives to the two approaches described above include injecting once own signing function directly and likely other options.

issues.title: strkey: Extract strkeys into a separate package to leverage `xdr` package.
issues.body:
I was suggesting you move this new code into a `strkeys` package, so that the implementations of different strkeys is independent from the `strkey` base package. As a bonus this would allow you to import `xdr` into `strkeys`.

_Originally posted by @leighmcculloch in https://github.com/stellar/go/pull/4279#discussion_r829359421_

issues.title: strkey: add str and payload length checks for all strkey types
issues.body:
In stellar/go#1796 a much needed check for the length and payload of public and secret keys are being to the respective `Is` functions.

As a follow up to that change, after that change is merged, we should build on it and make the decoding of all four types of keys perform those checks. We should also add or move those checks to `Decode` so that decoding and not just `Is` checks fail for keys that aren't valid.

We should wait to do this until stellar/go#1796 is merged, because that is adding a solid set of tests to build on.

issues.title: clients/horizonclient: possible error in tradesReq.BuildURL()
issues.body:
### What version are you using?

The following hash of the repo:
8791961449e584c1b8723e48adfa04371ff7e289

### What did you do?

```golang
tradeReq := horizonclient.TradeRequest{
	ForAccount:         accountID,
	BaseAssetType:      baseAsset.Type,
	BaseAssetCode:      baseAsset.Code,
	BaseAssetIssuer:    baseAsset.Issuer,
	CounterAssetType:   quoteAsset.Type,
	CounterAssetCode:   quoteAsset.Code,
	CounterAssetIssuer: quoteAsset.Issuer,
	Order:              horizonclient.OrderAsc,
	Cursor:             cursorStart,
	Limit:              uint(maxPageLimit),
}

// this should give a URL with the various base/counter AssetCode/issuer attached, but it does not
fmt.Sprintf("URL: %s\n", tradeReq.BuildURL())
```

I think this `if-else` condition might be the culprit:
https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/master/clients/horizonclient/trade_request.go#L44

The reason I think this condition ^ might be the culprit is because it only adds the filters for "trades" endpoints, i.e. it will not add it if we specify the offerId, accountId, or liquidityPoolID, which is not something that is expected when submitting such a request to the trades endpoint.

Not sure what changed in the code recently since the history doesn't seem to have affected this logic, but the code clearly reads differently from what is expected (and running the above sample logic demonstrated that the URL is built incorrectly)

### What did you expect to see?

I expected the URL to contain the filters passed into the `tradeReq` (specifically the asset filters) but they were not

### What did you see instead?

only the `cursor`, `limit`, `order` params were included

issues.title: strkey: check key length validation methods
issues.body: While checking Horizon diff I noticed that https://github.com/stellar/go/pull/1573 is not checking the keys properly. It checks if the values are properly encoded but it doesn't check the length of the keys (should be 32 bytes). Check js-sdk for comparison: https://github.com/stellar/js-stellar-base/blob/f9d03ce4ffe0989851d777abf2e934fdbf36b514/src/strkey.js#L119

issues.title: horizenclient: propagate client provided context
issues.body:
In Go 1.13, a new [function](https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/#NewRequestWithContext) `NewRequestWithContext` was introduced. It will be useful if the horizonclient can take a client-provided context and respect the context by using it to create a http request in [sendRequestURL](https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/787570f2f3dc6114baf5c96e5125a584319579e4/clients/horizonclient/client.go#L104).

This way, horizonclient can avoid making necessary requests or cancel a running request if the client-provided context has timed out due to the timeout they set or has canceled by the client. In other words, not only can the client of horizonclient have a better control of the request they are making but also have a clearer interpretation of the error.

For example, if the client (a server) knows that horizonclient errorred because the provided context has timed out, it can just return a timeout error to its own client.

issues.title: Feature Request: make CheckpointChangeReader a change reader and return diffs
issues.body:
<!-- Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks! -->

### What problem does your feature solve?
The `CheckpointChangeReader` type in the `ingest` package describes itself as a change reader, but really it only returns a complete snapshot of a checkpoint and not changes between checkpoints.

If an application is using checkpoints only for data and ingests a checkpoint at ledger X, and wishes to get the changes introduced in ledger X+64, the application will read the entire ledger state for ledger X+64 instead of only the changes that occurred. In this situation the `CheckpointChangeReader` will unnecessarily download and decode buckets that haven't changed.


### What would you like to see?

I'd like to see the `CheckpointChangeReader` updated to:
- Accept a starting ledger, which must also be a checkpoint ledger.
- Only download buckets that have changed between the two ledgers.
- Return ledger key deletes from the Read() endpoint.

I think this will probably require a change to the `Change` type as well because it assumes that any change we know about will include a complete view of the before (`Pre`) and after (`Post`) view of the ledger, which isn't the case in checkpoint ledgers, especially deletes where we will only know the ledger key of the item.

As part of experimenting with the `ingest` package (which is awesome by the way ðŸŽ‰ ðŸ‘ðŸ») I tried writing a small service that collects diffs between checkpoints using the changes above. An initial download of the entire ledger state takes about 2 minutes, and then reducing future downloads to changed buckets reduces that ingestion time to under 8 seconds, sometimes as small as milliseconds.

My hacky experimentation can be seen in this diff, if you look at the `ingest/checkpoint_change_reader.go` file: https://github.com/stellar/go/compare/master...leighmcculloch:frontier?w=1#diff-35c98eb7c476b5de267f7dc78959ec274fefe0c8726c59897ba1c56590c3017f.

### What alternatives are there?

Introduce a new reader that does this.

issues.title: Claimable Balance and Asset Summary Changes
issues.body:
The following changes to [claimable balances](https://github.com/stellar/go/pull/3483), and [assets](https://github.com/stellar/go/pull/3454) endpoints were recently released in Horizon 2.2.0:

- [ ] The Asset object now includes the following new fields, with examples:
```json
      ...
       "accounts": {
          "authorized": 23,
          "authorized_to_maintain_liabilities": 11,
          "unauthorized": 6
        },
        "num_claimable_balances": 3,
        "balances": {
          "authorized": "997268.0000000",
          "authorized_to_maintain_liabilities": "498634.0000000",
          "unauthorized": "249317.0000000"
        },
        "claimable_balances_amount": "124658.5000000",
        ...
```
- [ ] There is a new endpoint at `/claimable_balances/{id}/operations{?cursor,limit,order}`, to fetch operations for a given claimable balance.
- [ ] There is a new endpoint at `/claimable_balances/{id}/transactions{?cursor,limit,order}`, to fetch transactions for a given claimable balance.

Each SDK _must_ update to support the first item in the list, so that the `amount`, and `num_accounts` fields can be deprecated in Horizon v3.
Each SDK _should_ update to support querying operations and transactions for a given Claimable Balance ID.

The SDF's JavaScript SDK released [v8.2.0](hhttps://github.com/stellar/js-stellar-sdk/releases/tag/v8.2.0) recently including these changes.

If your SDK has implemented and released these changes, reference the release in a closing comment.

ingest/cdp: get latest ledger as default for unbounded range
issues.body:
<!-- Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks! -->

### What problem does your feature solve?
for uses cases of `cdp.ApplyLedgerMetadata` where caller just wants it to start a range at whatever is latest ledger of network, requires the caller to obtain the latest ledger manually from history archives first and pass that as range.from

### What would you like to see?
When caller of `cdp.ApplyLedgerMetadata` passes `UnboundedRange.from=0`, `cdp.ApplyLedgerMetadata` should detect and acquire the latest ledger internally and substitute that in the `UnboundedRange.from` value passed to BufferedStorageBackend.

An implementation choice needs be determined on how/which 'latest' ledger is obtained:
1) the checkpoint ledger from target network based on history archives 
2) the greatest ledger sequence that exists on the Datastore

If second option is chosen to use Datastore, then this ticket does become effectively blocked on https://github.com/stellar/go/issues/5498 which provides the changes on Datastore to facilitate.

### What alternatives are there?
callers of `cdp.ApplyLedgerMetadata` that want to start streaming from current network ledger, must manually call `HistoryArchive.GetLatestLedgerSequence()` first to obtain the latest sequence.

<!-- Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks! -->

Archivist verifies the tx set hash [here](https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/77cb331d374d53f632cd1571c96d07a8ec143dda/historyarchive/verify.go#L109), but starting from v20, `txSet` in `TransactionHistoryEntry` will be [empty](https://github.com/stellar/stellar-xdr/blob/bb54e505f814386a3f45172e0b7e95b7badbe969/Stellar-ledger.x#L260). Core instead hashes `generalizedTxSet` from the `TransactionHistoryEntry` extension, which archivist needs to do as well.

issues.title: stellar-archivist dumpxdr JSON has multiple roots
archivist: improve synchronization/repair of SCP history
issues.body:
### What problem does your feature solve?

Validators accumulate SCP messages that they witness when closing ledgers and upload SCP messages used to externalize specific slots.

Unlike other files, SCP history is not necessarily the same on all archives.

This can create the following problems:
* as validators can be configured with arbitrary quorum sets, SCP messages uploaded to a given archive represent the set of messages that was needed for that validator to externalize, which may differ from what a different validator with a different quorum set configuration may need
* validators do not always close ledgers with the rest of the network
   * for example, when a validator is offline for some time, it uses the current network ledger as trust anchor and "walks" history backwards to download from other archives. When replaying from history, validators do not close ledgers by witnessing SCP messages, and as a consequence do not upload SCP messages for some ledgers

### What would you like to see?

Archivist should allow repairing SCP archives by:
* at a minimum copy SCP files from other archives
* better is to merge SCP files from archives. Merging here would have to be done in such a way that 

### What alternatives are there?

A subset of this may be doable by modifying core to download SCP messages from other archives when replaying from history.
I am opening an issue there as "archivist" is more about fixing things up after the fact and core should just produce archives with enough information in the first place.

```log
created by github.com/stellar/go/historyarchive.(*Archive).ScanCheckpointsSlow
	/go/src/github.com/stellar/go/historyarchive/scan.go:69 +0x21d
```

<!--
If possible, provide a recipe for reproducing the error.
A complete working example or script is great.
A link on an online code editor is best. The following online editors are great.
 - JS: https://runkit.com or https://jsfiddle.net
 - Go: https://play.golang.org
 - Others: https://repl.it
-->

### What did you expect to see?
I expected `stellar-archivist` to report the results of the scan.

### What did you see instead?

`stellar-archivist` failed due to http endpoint being slow. I scanned the same archives using `s3:` endpoint and it succeeded. There should be an option in `stellar-archivist` to retry and fail gracefully with proper message if there's something really wrong with archives. This provides false positive results and it breaks automated scan for the Tier-1 history archives.

issues.title: Feature Request: stellar-archivist Generic Backend
issues.body:
<!-- Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks! -->

### What problem does your feature solve?
Currently it is not easy to interact with history archives hosted on Azure, GCP blob stores. Most users choose to sync from an existing history archive to their local file system and then use Cloud specific tools to push to blob stores but even this does not allow for `stellar-archivist scan` or `stellar-archivist status`.

### What would you like to see?
Ideally stellar-archivist is able to read a `put` and `get` command from a configuration file which would enable users to configure stellar-archivist read/write using external tools or shell scripts.

This would be inline with how stellar-core manages history.

### What alternatives are there?
Currently there are 2 alternatives, the first is to sync stellar-core from the genesis ledger on a full validator (>15 days) and the second is to use stellar-archivist to sync from http://history.stellar.org/ to a local file system and then push from local file system to cloud based blob stores manually using provider specific tooling.

Both of these solutions are cumbersome and neither allow monitoring of history archives via the `status` and `scan` sub commands.

issues.title: support/historyarchive: Fails instead of retrying on http 503 response. It also panics on a 429
issues.body:
### What version are you using?
master

### What did you do?
use `stellar-archivist` on the http endpoint of a google storage bucket

### What did you expect to see?
Retry when a GET results in a 503, random backoff and retry on 429

### What did you see instead?
`stellar-archivist` fails.

Note that this makes `stellar-archivist` unusable when using an http endpoint that may respond with 503/429 on occasion; on a long run, it invariably fails, since it is likely at least one 503/429 is encountered during the archivist run.

issues.title: all: replace support/errors with builtin stdlib errors
issues.body:
### What
Replace `support/errors` and our use of `github.com/pkg/errors` with using the builtin stdlib errors wrapping and unwrapping functions that are available since Go 1.13.

### Why
Now that #2325 is merged and we only support Go 1.13 and 1.14 we now have the capability to use features that were added in Go 1.13. The stdlib got new errors functions that support natively wrapping and unwrapping errors. We should use them to make our code more friendly to generic Go code. Even the original author of pkg/errors has stated he no longer uses the packages and this extra layer distances us from writing code that is understandable by an average Go developer because our errors just work that little bit different and causes our errors to behave in subtly different ways to native errors.

### Concerns
The pkg/errors errors give us stack traces with our errors, while stdlib errors still do not. This has been an area lacking consensus and so I doubt stdlib errors will gain stack traces soon. We shouldn't do this assuming stack traces might show up in a future release. If this is something we find extremely valuable we should probably not do this.

issues.title: HTTP Setup: Default WriteTimeout
issues.body:
<!-- Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks! -->

### What problem does your feature solve?
There is no default `WriteTimeout` in the setup of http server. If the server instance is used using a configuration without `WriteTimeout` it will be set to 0 which means `no timeout`. That may be an issue if a request takes too much time to process and can potentially lead to DoS the server.
We need to be careful how this value is set though. It should be more than ReadTimeout.

Those two articles provide useful information in my opinion:
* [So you want to expose Go on the Internet](https://blog.cloudflare.com/exposing-go-on-the-internet/)
* [The complete guide to Go net/http timeouts](https://blog.cloudflare.com/the-complete-guide-to-golang-net-http-timeouts/)

### What would you like to see?
A default value for `WriteTimeout` in [HTTP setup function](https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/fb9e9435abed40725cfeae9603bfb9addefff074/support/http/main.go#L91)

### What alternatives are there?
We already have a default `ReadTimeout` and [Go >= 1.13](https://go.dev/doc/go1.13#net) sets a [pretty aggressive TCP timeout](https://cs.opensource.google/go/go/+/master:src/net/dial.go;l=17), so this may be sufficient if our services does not let the client control parameters that influence the processing time of a request. But it is good practice in case there is a edge case.

issues.title: Feature request: new package `support/i128` to manage 128-bit math
issues.body:
### What problem does your feature solve?
Converting to/from integer types can be a huge source of bugs, and the use of `xdr.Int128Parts` will be prolific in the Soroban world as the de-facto way to represent amounts.

### What would you like to see?
A new package, `support/i128`, that deals with everything 128-bit related. This (non-exhaustive) list includes:

 - doing math on the value
 - correctly representing negative values in the unsigned "halves" of the XDR struct
 - safely converting to/from `int64` values which represent 
 - conversions to/from strings with varying degrees of decimal precision/representation

It's likely that there are libraries out there we can leverage or at least borrow code from, but it will still need to be custom to some degree to adapt specifically to the `xdr.Int128Parts` structure.

### What alternatives are there?
Chug along until it becomes a bigger problem.

issues.title: Validate path in path payment ops
issues.body: In https://github.com/stellar/go/pull/1776#discussion_r328262377 @tamirms noticed that path value in path payment operations is not validated. We should do it for both `PathPaymentStrictReceive` and `PathPaymentStrictSend`.

issues.title: price: Allow more decimal numbers in `price.Parse`
issues.body:
<!-- Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks! -->

### What version are you using?

`master`

### What did you do?

[`price.Parse`](https://godoc.org/github.com/stellar/go/price#Parse) is using `price.continuedFraction` internally. It checks if the given price is a valid Stellar amount using regexp:
https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/04ac85c94afe1fbb24e850601812f4c791926b24/price/main.go#L20-L26
https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/04ac85c94afe1fbb24e850601812f4c791926b24/price/main.go#L41-L47

This behaviour is incorrect. Requirement for amounts to have at max 7 decimal places comes from the way stellar-core keeps amount values internally (`int64` in stroops which is 10<sup>-7</sup> XLM). There is no such limitation on string representation of the price.

The regexp check appeared in the code around the time when we received security report about possible DoS vector when parsing amounts using [`amount.Parse`](https://godoc.org/github.com/stellar/go/amount#Parse) function. The argument value was passed directly to `big.Rat.SetString` which can start extensive calculations on values like `1E9223372036854775807` (note: `E`). This behaviour was incorrectly incorporated into `price.Parse` because it's using `big.Rat.SetString` internally too.

When fixing this issue we should remember about this DoS vector. Specifically, we should check what's the maximum number of decimal places we can allow to ensure low CPU usage.

issues.title: Feature Request: txnbuild: add ability to create TransactionParams from Transaction
issues.body:
### What
Add ability to create TransactionParams from Transaction.

### Why
So that we can load a Transaction, edit it, then resign it, etc.

As far as I can tell the txnbuild package does not contain functionality for this.

Since the way to provide parameters to a new Transaction is to use the TransactionParams type, it seems fitting that to modify a Transaction, which is largely immutable other than for signing, the method to do so would be to construct a TransactionParams from a Transaction.

There are plenty of use cases where different parties will sign a transaction, but then decide they need to modify it and resign it. SEP-8 is one example. Payment channels has a flow that will require it as well where a prior signed transaction stored as XDR will need reparsing, modifying, and resigning.

issues.title: Feature Request: Add support for clientDomain in BuildChallengeTx
issues.body:
<!-- Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks! -->

### What problem does your feature solve?
The function BuildChallengeTx does not support to add the clientDomain and the clientSigningKey into the transaction built.
See [here](https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/1dd5bb02c4da/txnbuild/transaction.go#L880).
### What would you like to see?
As you can see, the python SDK supports them:
Look at the source code, specifically the func [build_challenge_transaction](https://github.com/StellarCN/py-stellar-base/blob/master/stellar_sdk/sep/stellar_web_authentication.py#L68)

It uses 
```
:param client_domain: The domain of the client application requesting authentication
:param client_signing_key: The stellar account listed as the SIGNING_KEY on the client domain's TOML file
```
The after this [line](https://github.com/StellarCN/py-stellar-base/blob/master/stellar_sdk/sep/stellar_web_authentication.py#L114) we have
```
if client_domain:
        if not client_signing_key:
            raise ValueError(
                "client_signing_key is required if client_domain is provided."
            )
        transaction_builder.append_manage_data_op(
            data_name="client_domain",
            data_value=client_domain,
            source=client_signing_key,
        )
```
### What alternatives are there?
Is it viable to add support for them? I can send in a PR.

/txnbuild

issues.title: txnbuild: assets are trimmed on left and right but should be only trimmed right
issues.body:
<!-- Please answer these questions before submitting your issue. Thanks! -->

### What version are you using?

`master` at todays date which is:
`8f5ac1ca259b3842e4296d2a8804e919fcbc26fc`

Includes these releases:
`ticker-v1.2.0` `horizonclient-v2.0.0` `horizon-v1.0.0-alpha` `friendbot-v0.0.2` `federation-v0.3.0`

### What did you do?

Looking at the code here:
https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/14a482c1286875cee8caef5ec1fa2fdb27e923c3/txnbuild/allow_trust.go#L66-L73

### What did you expect to see?

I expected to see asset padding on the right to be trimmed, but I see us trimming padding on the left and right. I expected we only need to discard trailing `\x00`s and therefore should use `bytes.TrimRight` because when I've seen padding discussed in documentation (e.g. [SEP-11](https://github.com/stellar/stellar-protocol/blob/master/ecosystem/sep-0011.md#asset)) it is only used to pad the tail.

### What did you see instead?

I see the code trimming padding on the left and right of assets.

### Discussion

There is some discussion about this here: https://github.com/stellar/go/pull/3364#discussion_r562746279

This is unlikely to cause issues for most people because the common approach for padding is to pad on the right, but there could be edge cases where unexpected behavior arises.

cc @stellar/horizon-committers @2opremio

issues.title: clients/stellartoml: parser has become brittle
issues.body:
### What version are you using?

15de5ffd450223e1bc5abf80575d906dc2eabb6e

### What did you do?

I used the Stellar TOML client to retrieve stellar.toml's from a handful of domains.

### What did you expect to see?

I expected to see parsing to succeed.

### What did you see instead?

Some of the responses failed parsing because some of the bool fields are strings in anchor stellar.tomls. These two fields seemed to be the ones most commonly the wrong type.

https://github.com/leighmcculloch/stellar--go/blob/c6e9fc962c928ecea522e24b29b71faf99f3f71e/clients/stellartoml/main.go#L60-L61

These used to parse fine, but since we've added more fields to the client code in 70596c57feb6b51584df13c91f18d53cc4e5dbf4 this now doesn't pass for all stellar.toml hosts.

Clearly domains hosting stellar.toml files need to host valid toml files, but maybe we should be more tolerant to `'true'` vs `true` values. This issue is intended to be space to discuss this.

issues.title: txnbuild: Refactor validation for SetOptions operation
issues.body:
In #1707 we introduced a `Validate()` method to the `Operations` interface so that the required fields for the structs that implemented this interface can be validated. 

`SetOptions` operation already did similar validation in its internal methods and it was out of the scope of the PR to refactor it.
The goal of this issue is to remind us to move the validation logic into the `Validate` method of `SetOptions`

issues.title: clients/horizonclient: Add support for extra query params in requests to Horizon endpoint
issues.body:
Some cloud-based node operators (e.x. Blockdaemon) [require](https://support.blockdaemon.com/hc/en-us/articles/360024815051-Node-Authentication) an additional `?auth=...` query param when sending requests to the Horizon node.

While [client.sendRequestURL()](https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/master/clients/horizonclient/client.go#L42) with some additional logic can be used to get around this, it would be ideal if [client.sendRequest()](https://github.com/stellar/go/blob/master/clients/horizonclient/client.go#L25) could still be used to form requests with extra optional query params, so custom logic isn't required depending on the choice of node.

issues.title: exp/clients/horizon: implement retry logic for handling retriable errors
issues.body:
Some errors are retriable like the [stale history](https://www.stellar.org/developers/horizon/reference/errors/stale-history.html) error. It would be handy for the users if we have some retry logic embedded in the SDK itself. Alternatively we can provide a helper function for the users to handle retriable errors themselves.

Related to this we can probably add a field in the error object in the backend indicating whether this error is retriable or not so that Horizon client can act on it. cc @tomquisel
